awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: The Causes of Natural Variation in Protein Expression
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to understand how the genetic material of a cell, its DNA, controls the amount of protein each cell produces, how a cell's environment stimulates it to ramp protein production up or down, and how this response differs between individuals. To function, an organism copies specific genetic information from genes in its DNA to molecules called RNA and then uses that RNA as templates to make proteins. Proteins are the molecular machines that carry out the work of cells and give cells their identities. It is not clear what causes the amount of protein that cells make to differ between individuals. It is known that this can be caused by differences in how much RNA is made. However, individuals may differ in how fast they make protein from the same amount of RNA and also how quickly they recycle protein when it gets old. The research will measure RNA and protein levels in two different strains of budding yeast as they respond to mating pheromone. It will involve both broad surveys of many proteins and detailed measurements of a targeted set. While engaging in this research, students at a primarily undergraduate institution and a postdoctoral fellow will gain interdisciplinary training in the emerging field of evolutionary systems biology. Students from a junior high school will also be engaged in scientific discovery; they will collect wild yeasts from the air and from tree bark and identify their relationships to each other in the fungal tree of life, fulfilling the requirements of the Next Generation Science Standards recently adopted by California and Washington.


Specifically, the project seeks to systematically characterize the causes of divergence in protein expression temporal dynamics using a unique combination of high-throughput phenotyping, modeling, cellular resolution quantitative trait mapping, and targeted functional analysis. The mating pheromone response network of the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae will be used as a model system. The research will identify the contribution of variation in mRNA levels, protein production rates, and protein degradation rates to protein levels. Applying this approach to a network of genes will elucidate the general trends in how protein expression variation arises. Identifying the causal polymorphisms underlying protein expression variation will point to the molecular mechanisms for such variation. These project outcomes will have far reaching effects in the fields of evolutionary genetics and systems biology.

por.por_cntn:
This work was motivated by several unresolved questions about the relationship between mRNA and protein expression levels and their variation. First, a number of papers have concluded that the relationship between mRNA and protein expression levels and between mRNA and protein variation is weak, but this claims is contested in the literature. Second, many of the studies on mRNA-protein relationships investigate single timepoints or assume steady state conditions. However, both mRNA and protein expression are dynamic traits that respond to environmental fluctuations, and generalizations about the relationship between RNA and protein levels are often missing this temporal context.  Third, because technologies for measuring mRNA levels genome-wide have been available for over 20 years and are far more mature than their protein counterparts, a huge amount of data has been produced and analyzed that focuses on natural genetic variation at the level of mRNA expression. If mRNA levels really are only weakly related to protein levels, the relevance of this large body of work to understanding the basis of phenotypic variation would be undercut.

 

We used the response of the budding yeast Saccharomyces cerevisiae to mating pheromone as a model system to answer these questions. Upon exposure to pheromone yeast undergo a massive physiological and eventually a morphological response to prepare for mating. We looked at two strains of this yeast species ? a standard lab strain and a strain isolated from the lungs of an AIDS patient ? which were known to differ in their response to pheromone.  We measured both mRNA levels and protein levels genome-wide in each strain at several timepoints after exposure to pheromone. We found that the direction of mRNA change (induced or repressed) predicted the direction of protein change for around 2/3 of the genes and that only a few of the genes that differed in their protein timecourses between strains also differed in their mRNA timecourses.  There was ample evidence for mRNA-independent, protein-specific variation.

 

To better connect mRNA to protein, we mathematically modeled protein timecourses from mRNA timecourses by estimating protein synthesis and degradation rates. We found that during this pheromone response these rates demonstrably differed between strains for about 13% of genes. For some genes, strains had similar mRNA timecourses but these rate differences produced different protein timecourses.  For other genes, strains had different mRNA timecourses, but these were buffered during protein synthesis and degradation and led to similar protein timecourses.  Moreover, the synthesis and degradation rates could often change in a coordinated manner while still producing effectively the same protein timecourse, suggesting that there is space for these rates to drift without disrupting protein function. mRNA levels, synthesis rates, and degradation can be changed dynamically and independently and give evolution the flexibility to fine tune protein trajectories to meet specific cellular demands and also allow a population to build up a reservoir of variation that can fuel future evolutionary change.

 

This project provided training opportunities for undergraduates, masters students, graduates students and postdocs. It produced a hands-on lab exercise designed to teach CRISPR-Cas9 to secondary school students, and the ideas studied here comprised the core of several sessions on math, evolution, and biology for high school students.
